Situation1: Your I04iend has misunderstood the tone of your text message and replied sounding hurt. You need to call them right now to explain.
Situation2: An invited guest speaker has prepared a sermon and can take the pulpit if needed.
Story: I stared at my phone, heart pounding. My friend’s message was sharp, wounded—he’d taken my joke the wrong way, and now he thought I was mocking him. I knew I had to call him, to explain, to fix this before the hurt grew deeper. That’s what friends do: we talk things out, clear the air, make sure misunderstandings don’t fester. But as I reached for my phone, the mosque’s clock chimed. It was almost time for the Friday sermon. I was the imam, and the congregation expected me to deliver the khutbah, to guide them, to be present in mind and spirit. The guest speaker was ready, yes, but I’d promised the community I would speak today. My friend’s pain tugged at me, demanding my attention, while the weight of my responsibility as imam pressed down just as hard. I stood in the quiet of my office, torn between the call I needed to make and the sermon I needed to give, feeling the impossible pull of both worlds.
